title: 108_s377
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Commemorative Coin Act of 2003". Congress finds that Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. dedicated his life to securing the Nation's principles of liberty and justice, spearheaded the civil rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s, delivered his famous "I Have A Dream" speech at the March on Washington in 1963, advocated for nonviolent resistance, and was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964. Efforts are underway to secure Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s personal papers for the Library of Congress to preserve and study for future generations. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins with specific specifications, including weight, diameter, and composition. These coins will be legal tender. The silver for minting will be sourced from various available sources, including stockpiles. The design of the coins will be determined. The design of coins minted under this Act will reflect Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s human rights legacy. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various entities and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility during a 1-year period starting on January 15, 2004.

SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a $10 surcharge per coin, and costs related to designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. All surcharges from coin sales under this Act will be promptly paid by the Secretary to the Library of Congress for purchasing and maintaining historical documents related to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
